original_data.question: A 31-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department with fever, right upper quadrant pain, and myalgia. Her boyfriend says she recently returned from a trip to Southeast Asia. She appears ill and is lethargic. Her temperature is 39°C (102.2°F). Physical examination shows jaundice and tender hepatomegaly. Laboratory studies show the presence of anti-hepatitis A IgM antibodies. A liver biopsy performed at this time would most likely show which of the following histopathological findings?

options.A: Hepatocytes with shrunken, eosinophilic cytoplasm and pyknotic nuclei
options.B: Cystic spaces with scattered areas of cellular debris
options.C: Basophilic adipocyte remnants, filled with calcifications
options.D:
Engorged hepatocytes with red blood cell infiltration
"

model_response:
The answer is A: Hepatocytes with shrunken, eosinophilic cytoplasm and pyknotic nuclei. The clinical and laboratory findings are consistent with acute hepatitis A infection. Microscopically, the liver shows small hepatocytes with shrunken, eosinophilic cytoplasm and pyknotic nuclei. The other choices are not characteristic of acute hepatitis A infection.Diagnosis: Hepatitis A

question_entities.definition: Human females as cultural, psychological, sociological, political, and economic entities.
Hospital department responsible for the administration and provision of immediate medical or surgical care to the emergency patient.
An abnormal elevation of body temperature, usually as a result of a pathologic process.
A boy or man who is the lover of a girl or woman.
The geographical area of Asia comprising BORNEO; BRUNEI; CAMBODIA; INDONESIA; LAOS; MALAYSIA; the MEKONG VALLEY; MYANMAR (formerly Burma), the PHILIPPINES; SINGAPORE; THAILAND; and VIETNAM.
A feeling of general discomfort or uneasiness, an out-of-sorts feeling.
Characterized by a lack of vitality or energy.
The measure of the level of heat of a human or animal.
Systematic and thorough inspection of the patient for physical signs of disease or abnormality.
A clinical manifestation of HYPERBILIRUBINEMIA, characterized by the yellowish staining of the SKIN; MUCOUS MEMBRANE; and SCLERA. Clinical jaundice usually is a sign of LIVER dysfunction.
Antibodies to the HEPATITIS B ANTIGENS, including antibodies to the surface (Australia) and core of the Dane particle and those to the "e" antigens.
Removal of tissue from the liver for microscopic examination.

The microscopic study of characteristic tissue abnormalities by employing various cytochemical and immunocytochemical stains.
